V436 Per.source: DEBCat and Southworth & Bowman (2022) Table 3. Tess sector 18 SAP data analysed with JKTEBOP. Teffs reproduced from Janik et al. (2003)
V436 Per.details: 2 short cadence sectors (18 & 85); eccentric orbit with eclipse depths of ~0.4 and ~0.15 mag; long period means only one of each eclipse is observed; Star B is both larger (k~1.1) and more luminous (J~1.04) than Star A; Southworth & Bowman found LC solutions where k=0.69(3), 0.84(2) and 1.10(3), with that last adopted;
V436 Per.notes: not in TESS-ebs so ephemeris & morph defined here; jktebop_overrides and ephemeris from source work; sector 89 to be omiited as there is only one eclipse;

V539 Ara.source: DEBCat and Southworth & Bowman (2022) Table 3. Tess sectors 13 and 39 SAP data separately analysed with JKTEBOP (due to apsidal motion). Teffs reproduced from Clausen (1996).
V539 Ara.details: 4 short cadence sectors (13, 39, 66 & 93); eccentric orbit with eclipses of approximate depth 0.45 and 0.40 mag; apsidal motion results in significant phase shift for later sectors; primary fractional radius of 0.22 is beyond JKTEBOP's usually recommended maximum (0.2);
V539 Ara.notes: sectors 39, 66 & 93 omitted as jktebop throws gaussj errors (phase shift?); override teff_sys to more appropriate value for SpT;

MU Cas.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XXII, Table II. TESS sectors 17, 18, 24, 57, 58, 77 & 78 SAP photometry (120 s) analysed with JKTEBOP version 43. Refines characterisation of LacyClaret+04aj.
MU Cas.details: 9 short cadence sectors (17-18, 24, 57-58, 77-78 & 84-85); a pair of B5 V stars in a 9.65 d elliptical orbit; eclipses are approximately 0.45 and 0.44 mag deep with the secondary at phase ~0.62;
MU Cas.notes: distorted sections of S18 & 78 - both have low(est) pdc_tot so may be easily omitted; S77 has highest pdc_tot = 0.891; override teff_sys to more appropriate value for SpT;

IQ Per.source: DEBCat and Southworth24obsR21 with initial JKTEBOP v43 anlysis of TESS sector 59 and full analysis of sectors 19 and 59 with WD2004 code.
IQ Per.details: 3 short cadence sectors (19, 59 & 86); totally eclipsing system with an eccentric orbit and apsidal motion; eclipses are ~0.45 and ~0.15 mag deep with the secondary appearing before phase 0.5; an additional challange is presented by the primary B-type star which is pulsating;
IQ Per.notes: early part of S86 requires clipping to remove distortions;

AR Aur.source: DEBCAT and Southworth (2025) Tables II, III and IV. SAP flux at a cadence of 120 s from TESS sectors 19, 43, 44, 45, 59, 71, 73 & 86 separately characterized with JKTEBOP.
AR Aur.details: 8 short cadence sectors (19, 43-45, 59, 71, 73 & 86); a pair of late-B stars in a circular 4.135 day orbit; primary and secondary partial eclipses of depth ~0.6 and ~0.55 mag;
AR Aur.notes: sections of S73 and 86 require clipping; works well by taking the mean of the fits of each sector;

V1229 Tau.source: DEBCat and Southworth et al. (2023), Table I. TESS sectors 42-44 SAP flux analysed with JKTEBOP version 43. SpT originally from Abt & Levato (1978)
V1229 Tau.details: 5 short cadence sectors (42-44 & 70-71); an inclined, circular orbit with shallow primary (~0.10 mag) and secondary (~0.05 mag) partial eclipses, reflection and ellipsoidal effects;
V1229 Tau.notes: not in TESS-ebs so ephemeris & morph defined here;

V889 Aql.source: DEBCAT and Baroch et al. (2022) Tables 9 and 10. Used SAP flux extracted from TESS sectors 14 and 40 FFIs analysed with JKTEBOP and all params published. TESS sector 40 & 54 600 s timeseries data now available.
V889 Aql.details: A highly eccentric orbit with the secondary eclipse before phase 0.4. The eclipse depths differ despite the stars having similar radii and brightness, making k and J difficult to predict and fit. We use sector 40 timeseries data and the published spectroscopic light-ratio for fitting. Sector 40 shows some long term trends which our detrending is not removing however this does not appear to be overly detrimental to the predictions or fitting.
V889 Aql.notes: *** Having issues resolving this target in MAST ***
V889 Aql.author: TESS-SPOC

V596 Pup.source: DEBCAT and Southworth (2025) Tables II and III. Used SAP flux from TESS sectors 34 and 61 separately characterized with JKTEBOP v43.
V596 Pup.details: 3 short cadence sectors (34, 61 & 88); eccentric 4.596 day orbit with the secondary eclipse near phase 0.475; eclipse depths of ~0.45 & ~0.40 mag; the published work found evidence of delta-Scut pulsations and apsidal motion;
V596 Pup.notes: not in TESS-ebs so ephemeris & morph defined here;

WW Aur.source: DEBCat and Southworth et al. (2005) who use EBOP (with mods to fit rA+rB & k and to use MRQMIN) for fitting of observations from the 1970s. We use V-band fitting results (Table 10). Available TESS sectors 20, 43-45, 60 & 71-73 at 120 s cadence.
WW Aur.details: 8 short cadence sectors (20, 43-45, 60 & 71-73); an inclined circular orbit showing partial eclipses of approximately 0.64 and 0.55 mag; secondary nr phase 0.5 yet noticable phase shift on later sectors; published work based on legacy photometry whereas we have used TESS data;

V788 Cen.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) (Table 8) who use WD for fitting SAP flux of 2nd half of sector 37 (as least affected by starspots), leaving sector 10 unused.
V788 Cen.details: 3 short cadence sectors (10, 37 & 64); an inclined circular orbit with partial eclipses of ~0.19 and ~0.16 mag;

RR Lyn.source: Rediscussion VII, Table II (with third light). TESS sector 20 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41.
RR Lyn.details: 3 short cadence sectors (20, 60 & 73); an eccentric orbit with eclipses of approximately 0.35 and 0.25 mag and the secondary near phase 0.45; significant phase shift on later sectors; evidence of delta-Scuti & gamma-Dor pulsations;
RR Lyn.notes: ebop maven testing uses flatten for best fit of S20; sticking with S20 until we can extend flattening; will challenge an 'auto-flatten' algo as the phase shift is significant - a test with the params from the ebop maven data shows it doesn't transfer to S60 & 73 well;

V362 Pav.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) Table 8 who use WD for fitting of SAP fluxes of 2nd half of Sector 13.
V362 Pav.details: 2 short cadence sectors (13 & 66); an inclined slightly eccentric orbit with eclipses of ~0.2 and ~0.03 mag; secondary eclipse is shallow but total; clear ellipsoidal effect; star B is signifantly smaller, less luminous and less massive; published parameters include a significant negative third light value;

V456 Cyg.source: DEBCat and Van Reeth et al. (2022) Table 1. TESS sectors 14 and 15 fitted with JKTEBOP version 42. SpT and logLA from Bakis et al. (2014).
V456 Cyg.details: 4 short cadence sectors (14-15, 41 & 75); a tight circular orbit of just 0.9 d with deep eclipses of ~0.6 & ~0.4 mag; variability is seen in the light curve from pulsations dicussed in the source article; both fractional radii are > 0.2, outside the range normally deemed suitable for fitting with JKTEBOP, but it was used in the source article and ebop maven testing was able to achieve a similar fit;

GW Eri.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) who use WD for fitting sector 31 (table 8).
GW Eri.details: 2 short cadence sectors (5 & 31); an inclined circuler orbit with partial eclipses of ~0.27 mag; noticable ellipsoidal effect; the stars have similar radii and luminosities;

OO Peg.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XVIII, Table II. TESS sector 55 TESS-SPOC/SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
OO Peg.details: just sector 55 and only at 600 s cadence; a circular orbit with clear eclipses of ~0.38 and ~0.35 mag;
OO Peg.notes: not in TESS-ebs so ephemeris & morph defined here; mask out isolated section in S55;

CW Eri.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XVII, Table III. TESS sectors 4 and 31 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
CW Eri.details: 2 short cadence sectors (4 & 31); a slightly eccentric orbit with eclipses of ~0.46 and ~0.40 mag; evidence of ellipsoidal variation;
CW Eri.notes: mask out section of isolated & distorted LC in sector 4;

ZZ Boo.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XII, Table II. TESS sectors 23 & 50 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 42.
ZZ Boo.details: 2 short cadence sectors (23 & 50); a circular orbit with similar eclipses of ~0.65 mag each; the stars are of similar size and luminosity;
ZZ Boo.notes: tess-ebs period is half the actual value; mask isolated section of S50;

RZ Cha.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XXIII, Tables II & III. TESS sectors 65 & 66 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
RZ Cha.details: 2 short cadence sectors (65 & 66); a pair of F5 stars in a 2.83 d circular orbit; eclipses are partial with similar depths of ~0.4 mag;
RZ Cha.notes: not in TESS-ebs so ephemeris & morph defined here;

V570 Per.source: Rediscussion XIV, Table II. TESS sectors 18 and 58 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
V570 Per.details: 2 short cadence sectors (18 & 58); an inclined circular orbit with variability due to starspots & evidence of the ellipsoidal effect; shallow eclipses of ~0.11 & ~0.10 mag; the source characterisation used a spectroscopic light ratio to constrain the fit;
V570 Per.notes: unable to get the sector fits to agree - going to limit to S58 which has significantly higher pdc_tot (0.871 vs 0.591);

AN Cam.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion IV, Table II.  TESS sectors 19, 25, and 26 (timeseries data from FFI) analysed with JKTEBOP version 41.
AN Cam.details: 5 short cadence sectors (52-53, 59, 73 & 79); a highly eccentric 20.1 d orbit with the secondary eclipse near phase 0.8; eclipse depths of ~0.6 and ~0.5 mag; the primary eclipses are total and the secondary eclipses are partial;
AN Cam.notes: not in TESS-ebs so ephemeris & morph defined here; long period means we ideally want to fit multiple sectors, so we go with S52+53; will likely benefit from flattening;

IT Cas.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XIII, Table II (sector 17). TESS sectors 17, 24 and 57 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 43.
IT Cas.details: 3 short cadence sectors (17, 24 & 57); an eccentric orbit with low inclination; similar eclipse depths of ~0.7 mag; the two components are similar;
IT Cas.notes: maven tests use flattening but we get a good fit with or without;

V455 Aur.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion V, Table II. TESS sector 20 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41. TESS sectors 60 and 73 released subsequent to publication.
V455 Aur.details: A slightly eccentric, inclined orbit with eclipse depths of approximately 0.33 and 0.3 mag and a third non-eclipsing component in 4200 d orbit. While the eclipsing components are of similar radius their luminosities differ, with the source article publishing a light ratio of 0.859Â±0.031.

V505 Per.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion VI, Table II. TESS sector 18 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 41. TESS sector 58 observations released subsequent to publication.
V505 Per.details: An incloned circular orbit with similar primary and secondary eclipses of approximately 0.5 mag. The similarity of the components' radii will likely make predicting and fitting k and J challenging. There is some distortion of the light curve near BTJD 1791 which we treat with lightkurve flatten.

AI Phe.source: DEBCat and Maxted et al. (2020), Tables 2 and 3. The Southworth analysis of TESS sector 2 PDCSAP flux (K, JKTEBOP v38, quad LD law).  Teff and subsequently calculated L from Kirkby+Kent et al. (2016) table 8 best fit (alpha_ml=1.78/DeltaY=0.00)
AI Phe.details: An eccentric orbit with the secondary occuring before phase 0.5. Star B is significantly larger and evolved with k~1.6. Only sector 2 shows both eclipses with sectors 29 and 69 having incomplete eclipses. The primary eclipses are total and the secondary eclipses are partial. We use the parameters from Maxted et al. (2020) run K as our labels and effective temperatures and luminosities from Kirby et al. (2016).

ZZ UMa.source: DEBCat and Rediscussion XI, Table II. TESS sectors 14, 21, 41, 47 and 48 SAP photometry analysed with JKTEBOP version 42.
ZZ UMa.details: A circular orbit with total eclipses of approximately 0.65 and 0.35 mag and significant variability due to starspot activity.

QR Hya.source: DEBCat and Graczyk et al. (2022) table 8 who use WD for fitting TESS sector 9 PDCSAP data (omitted sector 36 due to starspots). Sector 63 released subsequent to publication.
QR Hya.details: An inclined orbit with partial eclipses of approximately 0.30 and 0.28 mag.

V530 Ori.source: DEBCat and Torres et al. (2014) who used JKTEBOP with various non-TESS photometry sources.
V530 Ori.details: A G+M pair in an eccentric 6.1 d orbit showing partial primary partial eclipses of ~0.5 mag and shallow secondary total eclipses of ~0.06 mag. Some variability detected, potentially from star spots.

CM Dra.source: DEBCAT and Martin et al. (2024), Table I. TESS Sectors 16, 19, 22-26, 49-52 (all slow) and 56-59 (200 s) analysed with EXOPLANET. SpT, Teff & logL from Morales et al. (2009).
CM Dra.details: Two M-dwarfs in a nearly circular, slightly inclined 1.27 d orbit. Eclipses are approximately 0.76 and 0.73 mag deep. Lightcurves show frequent flares however these should have little affect on the fit.
CM Dra.author: TESS-SPOC
